Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: SInRGI: A Shared, Integrated Resource for ?Global Impact?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Computer Science Institute proposes SInRGI (a Shared, Integrated Resource for Global Impact), a collaborative effort among APÂ® Computer Science Principles (CSP) projects that will curate and develop teaching resources for CSP's "Global Impact" learning objectives. As the first official CSP courses roll out in Fall 2016, teachers will be looking for creative, engaging instructional materials to cover the learning objectives detailed in its curricular framework. That framework is organized around seven Big Ideas, including Global Impact (GI). For most of the CSP Big Ideas, there is already a wide range of solid instructional materials available, but that is not yet the case for GI. At the same time, the GI learning objectives are furthest from the programming core
that has traditionally been the focus for many high-school CS teachers.

The SInRGI resource will be developed as a collaboration between the International Computer Science Institute (ICSI) and seven of the groups that have been developing content aligned to the CSP framework: The Beauty and Joy of Computing (BJC), CISS (Computing in Secondary Schools), Code.org, CS4Alabama/CSP4HS, CS Matters, Mobile CSP, and Thriving in Our Digital World: AP. Each group will each contribute materials, and then they will all work together to identify the best combination of approaches, and to create any new materials that are needed to fill gaps. This combined resource will then be distributed via the NSF-supported CS10K Community of Practice and other outreach channels. Finally the project team will work with providers of CSP professional development to
incorporate the new material.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The real-world impact of computing -- on society and on their own lives -- is an engaging hook that can stimulate students’ lasting interest in computer science. One of the most innovative features of the new AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) course framework is that it includes the Global Impact of Computing as one of its foundational organizing principles (“Big Ideas”). Many high school CS teachers were excited to see this “missing piece” incorporated into a major, influential CS education framework. But at the same time, exactly because it is innovative, many teachers were not certain how to approach it, and coverage within existing CSP resources was initially somewhat sparser.

 

The SInRGI grant funded a collaboration called “Teach Global Impact” (TGI) that brought together leading CS educators from seven excellent NSF-supported CSP curricula and professional development (PD) programs for teachers: The Beauty and Joy of Computing (BJC), Computing in Secondary Schools (CISS), Code.org CSP, CS Matters, CSP CS4HS (AKA CS4Alabama), Mobile CSP, and UTeach CSP.

 

The goal of the collaboration was to identify common challenges teachers face in presenting this unusual-for-CS topic, and to identify best practices and bring together or create resources for addressing those challenges. In particular, TGI aims to encourage and enable teachers to get comfortable with taking an interdisciplinary approach to teaching computer science -- especially with teaching students the necessary interdisciplinary skills (like cooperative learning, content-area reading, online research, and expository writing).

 

The Teach Global Impact website (teachglobalimpact.org) provides a comprehensive set of resources for teaching about the social impacts of computing -- in CSP or any other class. It includes a database of Global Impact lesson materials available from all of the collaborating groups, classroom strategy guides for teaching about social impacts, and an archived Computing in the News feed featuring student-curated stories. The project also produced new lesson materials, ensure coverage of major CSP framework points from a variety of angles and support a variety of teaching strategies. They include a lesson on how unintentional biases can lead to skewed results, a classroom simulation around net neutrality, and a video highlighting how computer science has enabled progress in genomics.

 

In addition to the combined resource, the ideas and strategies the collaborators shared as part of TGI have informed and improved each of the groups’ professional development programming, as well as being incorporated in updates to their curriculum content.

 

The main focus of TGI was on the AP CSP course and exam, which launched in SY 2016-17. However, the resources are intended to be useful to any CS teacher wanting to use the social impacts of computing to contextualize the skills they teach. By making it easier for teachers to explore the topic, and providing resources to help them teach it, TGI will hopefully encourage more of them to bring it into the classroom.

 

Changes in CS education impact how computer science is practiced -- and who it is practiced by -- down the line. Focusing on foundational principles and on the uses and contexts of computing (as a basis for teaching programming, rather than the reverse) has the potential to attract more young women and underrepresented minorities into CS. This in turn benefits the field of computer science (as students learn in the TGI lesson “Diversity Makes for Better Solutions”!).

 

In addition to increasing retention of young women and underrepresented minorities, the push to teach global impact anticipates that any student who goes on to a career in computer science and technology will benefit from an early grounding in the sorts of social and ethical issues that should be considered -- for example, why it’s important to make sure an app will work smoothly with a screenreader for the blind, or who might be harmed when private data is not encrypted. This, of course, has impacts down the road, as the students of today become the technologists of the future.

 

In other words, society as a whole can benefit when computing technology is designed by people who approach their work with questions about what goals it meets or what needs it fills; who it will benefit, who might not be able to benefit from it, and who it might harm; and how their assumptions about end users might affect the quality and usability of the product.

 

In addition, Global Impact content often highlights how computing impacts work in other fields. Getting students to think about these connections early on has the potential to inspire more future computer scientists to look for opportunities to make such impacts (and a framework for evaluating how beneficial those impacts will really be). For students who do not go into CS, having had a Global Impact component will help them make interdisciplinary connections and bring their computer science knowledge to bear in solving problems in their chosen fields.
